And Poe, steeped in the melancholic beauty of German Romanticism, draws upon this wellspring of darkness, shaping his own vision of a world where dreams are fragile and shadows stretch long.

Poe’s “Dream-Land” is a poem of echoes and whispers, of a world both familiar and strange. And in the heart of it lies the ghost of a German king, a reminder that even in the darkness, beauty and sorrow are inextricably entwined.

The applesauce lay slick and yellow on the linoleum, a stain against the sterile white of the D&D market aisle. A hazard, a precipice of sticky death. Jennifer Palmer knew this. She knew it in the way a man knows the bite of winter, the way a woman knows the ache of a lost child. It had been a half hour, a lifetime in the slow crawl of the late afternoon. Twice the warning had been given, twice the manager, Martin, had turned a deaf ear. Dinner, he'd said. No time for complaints. 

This wasn't the first time. Not by a long shot. Five other souls had fallen victim to this same treacherous path in 2009 alone. But Martin, he wasn't listening. Not to the whispers of the floor, not to the cries of the fallen, not to the gnawing fear in the pit of Palmer's own stomach.  

And now, she was down. The world tilted, a kaleidoscope of pain blooming in her back. The applesauce, a sticky monument to negligence, clung to her like a shroud.

The law, it was a fickle thing. But malice, that was a different beast entirely.  It was a darkness in the heart, a cold indifference to the suffering of others.  Could a judge see it in Martin's eyes?  Would he understand the weight of those unanswered pleas, the calculated disregard for human safety?

Palmer, she knew she had a story to tell. A story of a spilled apple sauce, a manager's indifference, and a back broken by a disregard for human life.  A story that might just demand retribution.

The air hung thick with ash, the dust of some old fire still clinging to the world.  Four years back, in a classroom lit by the cold glow of fluorescent tubes, I wrestled with the question of Islam, a question that seemed to fester, to grow more urgent with each passing day. Was this faith, this creed, inherently hostile? The news, a crow cawing in the wind, had shifted its tune since the towers fell. From a cacophony of fear to a hushed reverence.  Could a man like Barack Obama, a name like that, a whisper of 'foreign' blood in his veins, have dared to dream of the presidency back then?

The Prophet’s story, it drew me in, a tangled web of contradictions. I'd always thought of him as a warlord, a man who carved his empire with a sword and the lash of iron. But this account, this biography, painted a different picture. A martyr, misunderstood, a man who wore humility like a shroud. They said he didn't force their hands, didn't break their spirits, but simply spoke his truth, and truth, like a slow-burning fire, consumed the hearts of men.

And then there was the echo, the chilling similarity between the ministries of Jesus and this man, Muhammad. The feeding of the multitude, a simple act of sharing, a loaf of bread multiplied, enough to sate forty hungry souls. It was a cadence, a refrain, a theft of the divine, a whispering echo in the wilderness. 

The stories, they danced around their purpose. Distant voices, whispers passing from man to man, each retelling blurring the line between truth and fable. Proof, they claimed, but the echo of doubt lingered. 

No, what truly gnawed at me was the elevation, the attempt to cast Muhammad as a saint, a beacon of gentleness and wisdom. But history, a weathered stone, whispered a different tale.  Did those who followed him, those who swore their allegiance, truly know the man behind the myth?

The boy squinted at the dust-filled air, the sun a pale disc in the sky.  He’d heard whispers of a time before the ash, before the wind carried the memory of fire. A time when the green things grew tall and the rivers ran clear. He’d seen the pictures, faded and cracked, in his father’s worn book.

“Was it always like this?” he asked.

His father didn’t answer. They walked on, their boots crunching on the gravel road, the silence a shroud around them. The world had chewed itself up and spat out its bones.  The churches stood empty, their stained glass windows shattered, the silence inside thick with the dust of forgotten prayers.

He’d seen the signs, the fading scriptures on the peeling walls, the remnants of a faith swallowed by the dust.  He’d heard the stories, the whispers of a man who preached love and forgiveness, a man whose words had once burned bright. But the fire had died, leaving only ashes and cinders.

They walked on, the road stretching before them like a ribbon unwinding into the greyness. The boy coughed, a dry, rattling sound in the stillness.

“Did he even exist?” he asked, his voice barely a murmur.

His father stopped, his gaze fixed on the horizon. He didn’t turn, didn’t speak for a long moment. Then, he said, “Some things are buried too deep to know for sure.” 

He looked at the boy, his eyes shadowed. “But the questions,” he said, “the questions are all that’s left.”

The smoke hung low, a greasy shroud over the city. Buildings, black against the dying light, stood like sentinels of greed.  Inside, the machinery churned, a beast of iron and steam fueled by the sweat and sorrow of men.  These men, they were cogs in a machine they could not comprehend, driven by the relentless hunger for profit.  The owners, their faces turned away from the grime and despair, saw only numbers, felt only the echo of profit in their hearts.

Sinclair paints a picture, stark and unforgiving, of a corrupt heart.  The line of buildings, "clear-cut and black against the sky," speaks of a world consumed by darkness.  The smoke, "streaming away to the end of the world," is a symbol of the endless consumption, the insatiable appetite that devours all in its path.  The river of grime and waste, the stench of animal death, the shadows of men working themselves to bone-thin frames – all a testament to the heartlessness at the core of this system.

They worked in those factories, these men, their bodies broken, their spirits crushed.  A dollar, a meager wage, was all that stood between them and starvation.  Loyalty?  Decency?  These were words lost in the clamor of the machines, drowned out by the relentless churn of the gears. Sinclair lays bare their plight: "So from the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar."

There was no safety net, no solace in the face of this injustice.  The laws, if they existed at all, were mere whispers in the face of such overwhelming power.  Unions, meant to offer a shield, became another cog in the machine, siphoning off the meager earnings of the workers they were supposed to protect.

The men were slaves, bound not by chains but by circumstance, their lives a constant struggle for survival.  Sinclair's words, sharp and unflinching, echo the despair: "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery."

The light fades slow in these parts. A thin, gray light, like the leavings of a dream. Fitzgerald builds his world this way, with colors that whisper and bleed into one another. White and gray, they hang heavy, like the dust on a forgotten porch. He starts with them, these colors, laying them down like foundations. White for the shimmer of things, for the surface of things, the niceties.  Gray for the bone beneath, for the weight of time, the fading.  

He paints Daisy in white, a white girlhood worn like a shroud, a white dress catching the light, a white roadster slicing through the dusty air.  And Jordan too, draped in white, a wisp of smoke against the gray backdrop of the world. They move through the world in these shades, like ghosts themselves, their lives a blur of surfaces. 

But Fitzgerald, he knows the truth. He sees the grayness beneath the white, the emptiness at the heart of things. He shows us the gray of Gatsby's parties, the gray names on Nick's list, the gray cars rolling through the valley of ashes. The gray of the world that stretches out, endless and unyielding.  

And then, when you think you've seen it all, he brings in the reds and pinks. A splash of color against the drabness, a promise of something more. A red light, a flicker of life. But these are fleeting things, shadows in the twilight. They fade as quickly as they appear, leaving behind only the gray.

The sun beat down on San Diego, a constant, brassy presence. It coaxed the land to yield its bounty: tomatoes fat and red, citrus bursting with juice, greens that whispered of spring, squash the color of bone, broccoli heads tight and promising. Herbs, pungent and alive, filled the air with their sharp perfume. Peaches and lemons hung heavy on the trees, berries blushed beneath the leaves, bees hummed a lazy tune over the blossoms. Honey dripped from the combs, peppers glowed like fire in the sun. This was a land of plenty, a land where life pushed forth with a relentless, stubborn grace.

But beyond the bounty, there was a whisper, a yearning for something more. A hunger for a connection deeper than the earth's yield, a longing for a purity that transcended the market's call.  In this land of plenty, people craved the taste of something truer, something cleansed of the world's taint.

They sought it in the bounty of the soil, in the eggs laid by hens that scratched in the sun-baked earth, in the milk that flowed from contented cows, their bells a soft chime in the stillness.  They sought it in the whispers of the wind through the fields, in the rustle of leaves, in the quiet sigh of a faraway river. They sought it in the small, quiet farms that dotted the landscape, where the earth was treated with reverence, where the cycle of life and death was understood, not feared. 

These were the farms where the land was not just a source of profit, but a place of healing, a place of connection. They were gardens of life, nurtured by sweat and prayer, where the soul found solace in the rhythm of the seasons. And in these gardens, the spirits of the earth whispered back, promising a harvest richer than any gold.  

This was the promise that drew people to these places, to the small farms tucked away in the valleys, where the air was thick with the scent of rosemary and thyme. They came seeking a connection, a touch of the wild, a taste of something real.

The wind scoured the plains, carrying the dust of a dying world.  Culture, it whispered, a phantom word on the bleak air. Not a thing, not a place, but a ghost that clung to men, to their bones. A hollow echo in the silence. To say all Russians are stubborn, all Japanese accommodating - that's a fool's game. A firefly dancing in the dark. What good is knowing what a man *is* if you don't know what he *holds* dear?

When you walk into a stranger's world, you carry your own shadows with you. Your own beliefs, your own burdens, and the world you see is a fractured reflection of that. To truly understand, you must lay down your own ghosts, look past the surface, see the bones beneath the skin. Look into the eyes, not for truth, but for the tremor of fear, the flicker of hope.

Culture, it ain't just lines drawn on a map. It's the slow, steady thrum of the heart in a crowded room. It's the unspoken rules, the tight-lipped smiles, the way a hand touches another in a moment of unspoken understanding. It's the ghosts of a thousand years, whispering in the halls of your mind.

And there's the corporate ghost, too. The office walls, the suits, the unspoken codes of conduct. A company can be a kingdom unto itself, with its own laws, its own values, its own hunger. Some hunger for profit, others for power, others for something more elusive, something they can't even name.

Values, now those are the marrow of the bone. They tell you why a man fights, why he bends, why he breaks. What he holds dear, what he fears. A culture that prizes harmony will shy from conflict, while a culture that reveres the deal will see no shame in hard bargaining.

But remember, a negotiator can't just stare at the map and expect to find the treasure. He must listen to the wind, feel the earth beneath his feet, and look into the eyes of his opponent. For in those eyes, he might glimpse not just a face, but a soul. A soul that echoes with the stories of a thousand generations, a soul that holds the key to the heart of the matter.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” These words, taken from Psalm 14 of the scriptures, echo in the chambers of Anselm’s argument, a plea for the understanding of God’s existence.  Like Aquinas, who follows in his wake, they both wrestle with the same concept, seeking to prove the God of the Bible. To compare them fairly, we must assume their God is one and the same, a singular being, unchanging and immutable.  And yet, though both men offer compelling arguments, neither truly lays bare a wholeness in their defense.  They glimpse the truth, but the full picture remains elusive.

Anselm’s argument is a journey inward, a quest for God within the depths of the soul.  He posits that because God exists within our understanding, his nonexistence is nonsensical. The proof, he suggests, lies not in the world without, but in the knowing that resides within. This reliance on faith, the acceptance of that which cannot be empirically proven, is a cornerstone of Christian belief.

Aquinas, on the other hand, lays his foundation in reason and observation. He constructs a case for God’s existence based on five logical arguments: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. Each argument weaves a tapestry of logic, suggesting that the very fabric of existence points towards a necessary first cause, a God whose absence leaves gaping holes in the universe.  His approach, if successful, would provide a powerful tool for evangelism, a bridge to the faithful through the clarity of reason alone.

But both men, in their pursuit of the divine, leave us wanting. They offer fragments of the puzzle, but the full image remains obscured. The question lingers: is the proof of God to be found in the whispers of the soul or in the cold calculus of logic? Perhaps the answer lies somewhere in the space between, a place where faith and reason intertwine, where the heart and the mind find common ground.

The boy was born into the world sometime in the past, a prince they called Buddha. He wandered, searching, and in the end, he found silence in the heart of things. His words, they whispered down through the years, became the path, the Theravada way. It’s been a long time now, over two thousand autumns, and the path has forked, grown tangled in the woods. 

Take that island, Sri Lanka, a place where the sea winds sigh and the rain washes clean the bones of the earth. There, they still hold the water-cutting ceremony, a ritual of the old ways. Monks and the common folk alike gather, offering prayers and blessings to the river. A strange thing, this ceremony, for the boy who found enlightenment never spoke of such things.

These are the echoes of change, whispers in the wind. The path, it shifts, the stones beneath the feet rearranged by unseen hands. From the whispered chants in the temples to the quiet meditations of the monks, from the offerings placed on altars to the five precepts that bind the layfolk, the Theravada world has been shaped by forces unseen. 

Some forces come from within, from the heart of the community itself, the whispers and debates that ripple through the sangha. Others come from the outside, the world beyond the temple walls. Some are benign, indifferent, like the changing seasons. Others are hostile, claws that seek to tear at the fabric of belief.

But at the heart of it all lie the truths the boy spoke, the four noble truths that echo through the ages. Dukkha, the truth of suffering. Attachment, the root of that suffering. The possibility of liberation. And the path, the Eightfold Path, that leads to the end of suffering, the cessation of Sansara, the endless cycle of birth and death.

A long journey, this path. A journey of self-discovery, of facing the darkness within and without. It is a journey that continues, even as the world around us changes. And it is a journey that ultimately leads to the silence, the stillness, the peace that lies at the heart of all things.

The sun bleached bone-white over the border between them. The U.S. and Mexico. A long scar on the face of the world, a feud that ran deeper than the roots of the mesquite. Fifty-seven years it festered, from the dust of '36 to the heat of '93. A bad blood born of clashing creeds and ideologies, of ambition and fear. 

The war, they called it, 1846-48. A bloodletting, a taking. Texas, the Southwest, all swallowed by the hungry maw of the north. But the skirmishes, the whispers of war, they stretched back further, like the shadows on a sun-baked plain.  

It's a sickness, this rivalry, that bleeds into the bones of nations. A border fence, it ain't just stone and wire. It's a wall of suspicion, built brick by bloody brick. The U.S. and Mexico weren't alone in that suffering. It's the curse of neighbors, the touch of history's hand. Face it, a man can only drink so much whiskey before he starts seeing the devil in his brother's eyes.

Religion, a tinderbox.  Those folks in the north, they saw the Catholic church as a foreign beast, a serpent in the garden.  Just like the cold war, a battle of souls, a struggle for dominance. Only this time, the weapons were prayers and pronouncements, not bombs and bullets.

But it was the land, the soil itself, that sparked the fire.  Borders, they ain't just lines on a map. They're veins of greed, pulsing with ambition.  Bandits and outlaws, they danced on that line, testing the limits, pushing the boundaries.  And the blood spilled, like water from a broken barrel.

It took time, and a reckoning, for the fever to break. Mexico, she bowed to necessity, her fate entwined with the north.  The U.S., her hunger shifted, from land to commerce, from conquest to control. 

But the scars remained. A testament to a time when the world was young, and the hunger for power, it gnawed at the heart of men.

Fifteen years back, a sickness crawled into my bones, unseen, unwelcome. A nurse I was, chose it for the comfort it promised, a shield against the shakiness of childhood. "Always work," they'd said, "Folks always get sick." So the dream of science, of stories, faded. Yet there I was, forty-six, alone, with nothing but the hollow echo of what might have been. Fifteen years on disability, the gnawing hunger of emptiness. Nothing left but what's given, the daily struggle, the erosion of self. Nothing certain but the thought: I wouldn't have made it without the hands reaching out, the love pressed against my own. Because truth be told, when the world cracks wide, you find out how little strength you have.

Life, she throws hard things. Big ones, small ones, catches you unawares. No amount of planning can build a wall against every storm.  We hear talk of pulling ourselves up by bootstraps, of a ruggedness that built this land. But in those hard times, it wasn't grit that saw them through, it was the warmth of neighbor to neighbor, the sharing, the lifting each other up.  Wagon trains didn't cross empty plains, they crossed with hands clasped, hearts tied together.

So yes, be ready. Have your kit, your water, your food.  Keep a lantern burning, a firebanked. But don't forget the human touch. Get to know the folks next door. Build bridges, not bunkers.  Because when the wind howls, it's the whispers of kindness that will keep you warm.

The question of how life twists and turns, how it carves its path through the vastness, this has haunted men since the dawn of thought. Even now, the true nature of this sculpting, this dance of change, remains shrouded in mystery.  Scientists, like paleontologists poking at the bones of the past, have tried to decipher the language of evolution. They've used tools, these numbers and equations, to map the growth of shells, to trace the lineage of creatures. They speak of "ontogeny" and "phylogeny," of spirals and sutures, of whorls that wind around a central pillar, the columella, like a whispered secret.

But the heart of the matter, the very essence of this transformation, it remains elusive. We can measure the curves, the angles, the increments of growth, but what of the driving force, the unseen hand that guides this unfolding?  Is there a script, a set of rules that dictate this unfolding, or does it spring forth from some chaotic dance of chance and circumstance?  We stand on the shores of this vast ocean of life, gazing at the intricate forms that populate it, and we can only marvel at the mystery.

Take the Prunum, for instance, a creature whose shell speaks of ages past. Its spiral, a chronicle of growth, a testament to the passage of time.  We can map its whorls, its sutures, its aperture, but can we truly understand the forces that shaped it?  Can we capture the essence of its being in equations and graphs?

Perhaps not.

For the beauty of evolution lies not just in its complexity, but in its ineffable nature. It is a story written in the language of life itself, a story that whispers to us of the profound interconnectedness of all things, a story that, despite our best efforts, may forever remain just beyond our grasp.

The dust of mortality settled thick on the air in Indonesia. For a decade now, the numbers for babes and their mothers, those first fragile breaths, had held steady. A stagnant tide in a sea of progress. The country aimed for the stars, reaching for those Millennium Development Goals, those shimmering promises of water clean and sanitation sound. But the children, the mothers, they clung to the shore, their needs unmet, their futures uncertain.

There'd been whispers of progress, a sliver of light in the darkness. More births attended by a hand skilled, they said, seventy-two percent now. But a hand skilled could be a midwife's, a weathered hand, not always capable of wielding the sharp tools of medicine when the night took a turn for the worse. And so the mothers bled, their lives spilled like water on cracked earth. The children too, they faltered. Fewer treated for the scourges that stole their childhoods, the killers that lurked in the shadows of every home.

Cesarean births, like pale ghosts, flitted through the land. A mere four percent, a whisper against the tide. And even here, a jagged line ran through the country, dividing the rich from the poor, the urban from the rural. Seven percent in the cities, a glimmer of hope, but a mere two percent in the villages, a hollow echo.  And the chasm widened, the poor left behind, their cries unheard, their access to care a distant dream. 

They spoke of solutions, of programs, of a quick fix, a bandage for a gaping wound.  But the question lingered, a shadow in the twilight: would it be a poultice or a cure?  To patch the holes, to mend the broken, or to build a foundation strong enough to withstand the storm?  Programmatic approaches, they promised, swift and sure, but at what cost?  To pour resources into one corner, to draw away from the others, was to leave gaps in the fabric of care.  And what of the human cost, the hearts and minds drawn to the bright lights, leaving the shadows behind?

The grip of Victorian fiction, with its meticulous detail and fixation on the aristocracy, loosens in the faces of novels like *Oliver Twist* and *Wuthering Heights*.  These two works, though born in the Victorian era,  venture beyond its conventions, embracing mystery and the unsettling,  a departure that  deepens the characters within them,  illuminating their motives and emotions in ways that are both profound and unsettling.

"A host of bewildering and confusing ideas crowded upon his mind. He seemed to still walk between Sikes and Crackit, their angry voices, their very words, ringing in his ears. When he turned his attention to himself he found he was speaking to them… Suddenly, he recoiled at the sharp report of gunfire. Loud cries and shouts rose, lights flared before his eyes, and all was a maelstrom of noise and chaos, as if some unseen hand bore him away in haste. Through these fragmented visions, a persistent, gnawing pain ran like a thread, wearing him down, tormenting him ceaselessly." (Dickens, 220)

Mystery, often woven through dream sequences or dreamlike states, drives both novels.  In *Oliver Twist*, these strange occurrences offer glimpses into Oliver's inner world, revealing his pain and his growing understanding of the harsh reality surrounding him. When the shooting of Oliver is revisited in chapter 28,  he relives it vividly, as if in a dream, while he seeks help. This passage underscores Oliver's lack of control over the events that have unfolded, and the dire state his health has reached. His hallucinations of Sikes and Crackit amplify his despair. The shooting overwhelms him; his senses numbed, he doesn't notice the "unseen hand" carrying him away. He re-experiences his despair, detached from the initial shock of pain, replaced by a constant, gnawing fear. The incident raises questions about whose will has brought about his misfortune. It certainly wasn't his own. This shooting reinforces Oliver's sense of helplessness, as he fails to even attempt to influence the outcome of events, even when his life hangs in the balance. A growing resignation and defeat in Oliver is implied, as if Fagin has broken him, forcing him to accept this despair, hindering his ability to react.  Had he not been broken, one would expect Oliver to at least try to fight for his survival. 


"The day passed – or did it? There was no day; it was gone as soon as it came – and night descended again; night long, yet fleeting; long in its dreadful silence, short in its passing hours."

The dust kicked up by the boy's worn shoes hung heavy in the air. He was small, maybe eight or nine, eyes the color of a winter sky. Worked with the other kids at the after-school program, tried to help them with their books. Me, I was good with words, stories. But this boy, Adrian, he was different. Letters he knew, some, but others... they seemed to twist and turn in his head, nonsensical sounds spilling out.  An odd thing, a boy speaking English clear as day, yet stumbling on the alphabet.  His mother came in one day. Couldn't say a word of English. Just Spanish, her words a tangle of sounds I barely understood.  But it clicked then, a cold certainty. The boy, he knew how to read, just not the English letters. Like a song in a language he'd never heard.

I tell this story, because language is a wall, brick by brick, and sometimes the mortar crumbles. California, with its tongues a tapestry of sound, it's a place where this wall is thick, and children fall through the cracks. Adrian, he was lucky. A little tutoring, some extra help with the alphabet, and the world opened up for him. But others, they stay lost. 

The solutions, they're not simple. Dual language programs, good in theory, but need more than just good intentions. Bilingual aids, tutors, teachers... it takes a village. And mainstream immersion?  It's a gamble, a hope that the child will somehow learn by being thrown into the current.  But there's no single answer, no magic spell. It takes all of them, woven together, to bridge the gap.

The rain hammered on the tin roof, a drumbeat to the slow dying of the light. We sat on the porch, me and my father, smoke curling from our cigarettes like prayers to a deaf god. He'd gone thin, bones poking through the skin, clothes hanging loose on his wasted frame. His eyes, though, they still held a flicker, like a dying ember in the ash.

"Cardinal," he said, when I asked about his favorite bird. His voice rasped, dry as the leaves clinging to the skeletal branches outside.

He looked out at the rain, a look that spoke of things seen and lost, memories swallowed by the downpour. I wanted to ask him about them, about what haunted those eyes, but the words caught in my throat. 

We sat in silence, the rain drowning out the sound of our own breaths. The shadows lengthened, the world shrinking to the porch and the rain and the man who was my father, fading away.

Months later, the rain still fell. A different kind of rain now, the kind that falls on graves. December had come, a cold fist squeezing the life from the world. My father was gone, the chemo and the radiation only delaying the inevitable. 

They said he died peacefully. That he'd breathed his last surrounded by loved ones. But I wasn't there. Couldn't bear to be there. Watching life ebb away, the light in his eyes dimming, a mirror reflecting my own fear. I knew better than to look. I knew he wouldn't want that.

So I stayed away. Closed myself in my room, the rain a constant drumming on the roof, a dirge for a life lived and lost.

They say God is a comfort, a light in the darkness. But all I saw was the darkness. The rain, the empty chair, the silence that echoed with his absence.

No one called, not even to tell me he was gone.

And in the empty space where he used to be, all I heard was the rain, whispering its empty promises.

The Gothic, they say, is a bastard child of contradiction, an oxymoron born of “Old-New.”  Watt called it that, saw it as a thing both steeped in the past and a harbinger of what was to come.  Some dismiss it as shallow, others exalt it for its terror, its “terrible sublime.”  Walpole, he who birthed this thing, claimed to be writing a “Gothic Story.”  He took the old, the theatrical, the ghosts of forgotten plays, and wove them into the new, the form of the novel, this window into the soul.  He gave us the monster in the shadows, the hero grappling not just with the external but with the darkness within. 

It’s a  beast with roots sunk deep in the mud of medieval castles and crumbling cathedrals, in the shadows of the knightly order, that chivalric ideal.  But “Gothic” was a word already stained with the dust of ages, a relic, a thing to be cast aside in the face of progress.  And yet, it lingers.  The Gothic, it finds purchase in the human heart, in the way we crave the familiar and the unknown, the comfort of shadows and the dread they cast.  

Walpole,  he saw the world unraveling, a society adrift in a sea of uncertainty.  He looked back to the knight, the image of honor and strength, and wove it into his tale.  Frederic, the prince, the fallen hero, he is a man shaped by loss, haunted by the ghosts of a better time.  He is the Gothic ideal, flawed but striving, a mirror reflecting our own fears and desires.

The road stretched out ahead, a grey ribbon unwinding through a landscape scrubbed clean. Dust, fine as bone meal, hung in the air, catching the light of the pale sun like a shroud. This was the chain, he thought, the thread that linked things. From the clamor of the want, the hunger in the belly of the market, to the raw materials dug from the earth, to the factories where metal groaned and gears ground, to the trucks that rumbled across the empty plains, delivering their precious cargo to the hungry maw of the customer.  It was a process, a dance of necessity, and he, a driver on this road, knew its steps by heart. 

They called it supply chain management, a sterile name for a dance as old as civilization itself. It was Oliver, a man with a name as cold as the steel of a machine, who first coined the phrase back in '82. He saw the system, the interconnectedness, and gave it a name. Six elements, he said, six pillars to hold up this vast structure. Production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, information.  Each one a cog in the wheel, each one vital to the whole.  

Production, the heart of the dance. The forge where raw materials were molded into something new, a symphony of clanging metal and roaring fire.  It was here the decisions were made, the blueprints scrawled, the orders issued.  The market, a hungry beast, demanded its due, and production answered with a steady pulse. Managers, the conductors of this orchestra, read the market's whispers, its sighs and screams, and translated them into language the machines understood.  They knew the rhythm, the ebb and flow, the need to anticipate the next beat.  

Supply followed close behind, the veins that pulsed with the lifeblood of the chain.  The source of the raw materials, the partnerships forged, the deals struck.  Managers, like shepherds, guided this flow, ensuring the right materials arrived at the right place, at the right time.  They knew the weight of each barrel, the fragility of each component, the cost of delay.

Inventory, the stockpile, the waiting room where goods gathered before their journey.  Managers, the gatekeepers, watched over this hoard, balancing the need for enough with the cost of storage. They knew the dangers of excess, the fragility of neglect.

Location, the crossroads, the nexus where decisions were made.  Managers, the cartographers, mapped the landscape, weighing the costs and benefits of each potential site. They knew the importance of proximity, the value of access, the need for efficiency.

Transportation, the arteries, the veins that carried the goods across the land.  Managers, the navigators, charted the courses, choosing the safest, the fastest, the most economical routes. They knew the dangers of delay, the cost of lost time.

Information, the pulse, the heartbeat of the chain.  Managers, the interpreters, gathered data, analyzed trends, and shared knowledge.  They knew the power of information, the ability to anticipate, to adapt, to respond.

Each element, a piece of a puzzle, a cog in a machine.  And the managers, the keepers of the chain, the ones who understood the rhythm, the flow, the vital dance of supply.

The sign hung crooked, a whisper of anarchy against the gray backdrop of the city. "Hitler is alive in Burma," it proclaimed in scrawled, black marker. Beneath it, Ellen Page stood, a ghost of a celebrity, her face pale and drawn against the dust-choked air. Burma, they called it now. Myanmar. A land choked by the iron fist of a junta, a place where silence was the only law.

The year was 1962. A coup had ripped the country apart, a shadow cast long over the land. The whispers of dissent, like dying embers, flickered and died. Then, in 2007, a spark. A flame ignited in the saffron robes of the monks, a revolution born of the color of their faith. The Saffron Revolution. They marched, chanting, their voices rising like a tide against the tide of tyranny. 

The government, blinded by fear, struck back. The peaceful protests turned to a maelstrom of violence. Monasteries, once sanctuaries, became battlefields. Journalists, chroniclers of truth, were corralled and silenced. Kenji Nagai, a Japanese soul seeking to capture the world's pain, fell, his camera a silent witness to the brutality.

The official death toll, a lie whispered on the wind, claimed 13 souls. Colonel Hla Win, a man who had seen the darkness, spoke of a horror far greater. "Several thousand," he murmured, his voice a broken echo of the truth.

This, though, was nothing new. From the Caesars, who claimed divinity, to the Japanese emperors, whose godhood was a twisted mask for tyranny, the hunger for power had stained the world red. Even now, in this land, where a president held court with a man who led a cult of the ignorant, the thirst for control remained.

Tiananmen Square, 1989. A sea of students, intellectuals, workers, dared to dream of freedom. The tanks rolled in, crushing their hopes under their treads. The official story spoke of 200-300 dead. The truth, whispered in the shadows, spoke of thousands.

Rwanda. The genocide, a stain on humanity's soul. A Hutu-led slaughter that consumed Tutsis and moderates alike. The air thick with the stench of death.

And then, the Third Reich. Hitler's shadow, long and dark, stretched across Europe, consuming millions in its fiery embrace.

The sign, a testament to the enduring fight against oppression, seemed to crackle with a quiet defiance. "Hitler is alive in Burma". A lie, perhaps. But a truth that resonated with the ache in the heart of the world.

The Duke, they called him. Ellington. His music, it clung to you like smoke, a slow burn in the bones. He'd carve out a sound, a world, with his piano, but it was his orchestra, his men, his women, that made it sing. Not just notes, no. He gave them space to breathe, to wail, to speak their own truths in the music. Each man, a voice, a color against the dark canvas of his arrangements.

He didn't just write for the piano, he wrote for the soul. A piece, it wasn't just notes on a page, it was a story waiting to unfold. A city, a dream, a memory. He'd lay down the framework, the bones, and then let his players' spirits take over.

They said it in the books, those Grove Music fellas. "Creole Love Call," they called it. Voice, not words, but pure sound, like a sigh on the wind. A conversation, a whisper, a scream, all wrapped up in the music. He used his men, those singers, those hornblowers, like instruments themselves, weaving their voices into the tapestry, each thread unique, each one adding to the whole.

Hot and Bothered, that's another one. A trumpet, a voice, a conversation in that smoky backroom where the music never sleeps. Two souls talking, each note a heartbeat, each breath a shared secret. He knew how to make the instruments sing, to make them feel, to make them bleed.

And then there's "It Don't Mean a Thing," a trombone, the voice of that man Nanton, mournful and beautiful. He knew how to find the heart of a sound, how to make it sing.

The need had always been there, a gnawing hunger in her soul. It began when she was fourteen, a girl on the cusp, and hadn't subsided three years later.  She'd come to understand it wasn't for things, but for someone.  Yet, no boy had ever stirred the embers of desire within her. Some had tried, clumsy and awkward in their pursuit, but she remained untouched, a fortress of indifference.  She questioned herself, searched for an answer in the labyrinthine corridors of her own mind. Theories flickered and died, leaving her in the cold silence of uncertainty.  She lived, adrift in a sea of unanswered questions.

Her days at home were usually peaceful, a haven of calm in a world that often seemed to spin too fast. Her parents, salt of the earth, moved through life with a quiet grace, their love a constant, unwavering presence.  Arguments were rare, a foreign language in their home.  The only discord came from her own rebellious spirit, her need to carve her own path, a solitary flame against the backdrop of their quiet contentment.

But this day was different.  A discordant note struck the harmony as she moved through the house, searching for inspiration, when a cry, sharp and thin, sliced through the air. Her mother's voice, strained and filled with pain, echoed from the kitchen.  Panic clawed at her throat as she ran, "Mom! Mom, what's wrong?"  

She found her mother on the floor, a tableau of pain and vulnerability.  Her breaths came in ragged gasps, each one punctuated by a soft "Ow."  Her daughter knelt beside her, a wave of fear washing over her. "Okay, Mom, just tell me where to take you."

Her mother's voice, weak and strained, directed her hands with a trembling urgency.  In that moment, the strength she'd built in her own body, a testament to her restless spirit, became a beacon of hope.  She lifted her mother, the weight a burden and a blessing, and carried her to the car.  


The hospital smelled of antiseptic and fear, but her mind was a storm of concern, focused solely on her mother.  She rushed her inside, her voice a frantic plea for help.  A blur of faces, white coats, and hurried words surrounded her as they wheeled her mother away. She was left alone, the weight of her mother's fate pressing down on her, a heavy silence filling the space where her mother's laughter usually resided.

The story, when it was finally pieced together, was a simple one.  A fall from a stool, a reach for a vase, a misplaced step. But the simplicity couldn't mask the terror that had gripped her heart.

The dust of the world clung to everything.  A woman's life, a study, a diet. All reduced to numbers.  They called it the Mediterranean, a name like a ghost, a whisper from a world that had gone. Like a dream of olive trees and sun-drenched stones, a memory of warmth. But here, the air was thin and dry. 

They wanted to know if this diet, this aMed, could hold back the tide of sickness. Could it ward off the cold grip of heart disease and the sudden, brutal blow of a stroke? 

They followed these women, 74,886 of them, their lives laid out like a map, their food choices recorded in meticulous detail. Questionnaires, they called them, these scraps of paper holding the weight of years. They asked about the things they ate: the fruits, the nuts, the fish, the oil that tasted of sunlight. And the things they avoided: the meat, the fat, the things that rotted the body from within. 

The women's lives unfolded against the backdrop of a relentless march of time. They watched as years bled into decades, as bodies changed, as shadows grew longer. Some women fell ill, their faces etched with pain, their breaths shallow and quick. Others lived on, their lives a testament to resilience, a flicker of light in the encroaching darkness. 

They measured their lives in numbers, in risks and ratios, in the bitterness of aspirin and the fleeting comfort of a multivitamin. They looked for patterns, for threads that might unravel the mysteries of life and death.

And in the end, what did they find? A glimmer of hope. A whisper of possibility. The women who ate like the sun, they found, lived longer, healthier lives. The women who clung to the shadows, they withered away.  

It wasn't enough, of course. Not a cure, not a guarantee. Just a glimpse of a world where life might hold a little more light, a little more warmth. A world where the dust could settle, and the sun could shine again.

The country broke in '07. A sickness in the bones of the world, spreading through the veins of the banks. Men in suits, eyes glazed with greed, had built towers of paper promises, stacked high and blind to the rot at their core. Houses, mortgages, futures, all traded like cattle, bought and sold with whispers and lies. 

They called it a crisis, a recession, a downturn. But it was more like a death rattle, a slow strangling of the soul of the nation. The old ways – work, sweat, honest toil – forgotten, replaced by the quickening pulse of a market that devoured all in its path. Clinton, he'd loosened the reins, thinking he could ride the beast. He sought to extend his own power, but the beast had other plans. It didn't care for presidents, for policies, for promises. It devoured them all.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, their names whispered in the smoke-filled rooms where deals were struck. They were the feeders, funneling the poison into the veins of the people. Mortgages like cheap whiskey, easy to swallow, leaving a burning in the throat but a false promise of comfort.

Holmes, he saw it coming. A prophet in a newspaper, his words stark against the glittering facade. He spoke of trouble, of a storm brewing, a government rescue. But the music played on, the dance continued, and the storm broke.

The houses, they ceased to be homes. They became numbers, assets, collateral. The people, their dreams stuffed into the pockets of the wealthy, left with nothing but empty rooms and hollow promises.

And the banks? They rotted from within, their arteries clogged with the sludge of bad loans. The giants fell, one by one, their collapse echoing through the canyons of Wall Street.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, names whispered in fear. They survived, transformed, their claws sunk deeper into the flesh of the nation.

Fannie and Freddie, they were the casualties. Their names now synonymous with failure, their bodies propped up by the very government they had served.

The air is thick with the smell of ash, the taste of dust. The ground trembles, the foundations crack. The people stand, dazed and uncertain, in the ruins of their dreams.

And the question remains: how do we rebuild? How do we stand against the tide of greed and folly? How do we find our way back to the light?

The air hung thick with the scent of dust and ash, a perpetual haze settling over everything.  It clung to the back of his throat, a gritty reminder of the world that had been consumed.  He tightened his grip on the boy's hand, their fingers intertwined like the roots of ancient oaks clinging to a crumbling hillside.  They were moving south, fleeing the relentless chill that had seeped into the bones of the land.  Winter was coming, a predator stalking the horizon, and they had to outrun it.  

The boy, his eyes wide and reflecting the faint light of the dying sun, looked up at him, his voice a small whisper against the wind. "Are we going to die?"

He squeezed his hand, a silent reassurance. "Not now," he rasped, his voice rough from disuse. "Not yet."  

They walked in silence, the only sound the crunch of dead leaves underfoot and the boy's soft breathing.  The world stretched out before them, a desolate canvas of ash-covered fields and skeletal trees reaching towards a sky choked with smoke.  A city, once a monument to human ambition, now lay in ruins, a jagged scar on the landscape.  It was a place where ghosts walked, where memories lingered like the scent of smoke and decay.  They had seen things along the way, things that would haunt their dreams for years to come.  But they pressed on, driven by a desperate hope for a future, for warmth, for a world where the sun still shone and the air was not thick with the taste of ash.

The screen flickered, a pale ghost of light in the dusk. Two voices, distant and hollow, droned out stories from a city named Columbus, Ohio. The first, an NBC dispatch, a man, a name – Shad Hostettler – a face, a cold stare, a mugshot in the flickering gloom. Ashley. Ohio. Stabbing.  The wife nameless, a shadow in the brief account. Evil, the word hung in the air, a thin, acrid taste. Two minutes, they gave it, a passing glance.

The next story, Travis Buyers, eighteen. A young whisper, cut short in the Sharon Woods. Shooting, critical, no names, no faces. A shadowy figure, a black hole where a life should have been. The SWAT team moved in, silent, efficient, but the story itself, brief, hurried,  like a bird fleeing a sudden storm.  A stain on the edges of the screen, barely there. 

A .22.  A helicopter, a wound in its side, a story of violence against the sky. A five thousand dollar reward, a whispered plea for justice. The city held its breath.

Rain. Thunder. A weekend forecast, a promise of a storm. A fleeting glance, a nudge to keep watching.

Then,  a robbery. A Clime Road UDF.  A dark figure, a hoodie, 
a weight of words, an insistence on color. Six-foot tall, one hundred and fifty pounds. Black.  

A drug kingpin, Rene Rodriguez, a name from Texas, a legacy of marijuana, 300 months.  A Hispanic man. A statistic, a label, a cold whisper in the night.

The screen flickered again, the voices faded, and the darkness returned.

The blood ties bind, they do. A brother to a brother. A knot that can't be untied, no matter the tangle. It's a thing of darkness and light, woven with love and hate, pride and scorn. A brother sees his own reflection in the eyes of another, clearer than any mirror. He sees the good and the bad, the truth that hides from the world. And when the world turns dark, that bond tightens, reveals its true heart. 

It's a costly thing, this understanding. The weight of it crushes you down, leaves scars you can't hide. But in the shadow of that knowledge, you learn what it means to be a man. You learn what it means to be bound.

They walked through a world painted in the colors of decay, two brothers against the dying light. A journey, futile and desperate, etched across the landscape like a scar. Pride, sharp and bitter, clashed against the desperation of hope. Blood spilled in the fading light, and only one man walked away.  

The older brother, he saw himself in the younger, a reflection warped by time and circumstance. His own failings, his own hunger for a world that wasn't there, they stared back at him.  He saw the boy, Doodle, as a burden, a shadow clinging to his heels. But in the depths of that shadow, he saw a spark. A flicker of life that mirrored his own.

He tried to teach him, to break him free of that fragile shell. To mold him into the warrior he wished he could be. But the boy, he was born broken. A fragile bird with clipped wings.  And the older brother, he was the one who clipped them. 

The world around them, it was a canvas painted in shades of gray. The air hung heavy with the scent of decay. It was a world that mirrored the darkness in their hearts.

The mind. A tangled thicket. A whispering canyon. They called it a machine once. A clockwork thing. Then a loom, weaving patterns from the threads of sense. Now they speak of circuits and algorithms, but the truth is darker. The brain is a cave, a labyrinth of shadow and bone, where the echoes of experience cling to the damp walls.

It takes in the world through senses, raw sensations like water seeping through a sieve. Touch, taste, sound, sight – these are the building blocks, the primal stones. But the mind, it shapes them. It twists, it turns, it carves meaning from the chaos.

Imagine a box, a black void on a white expanse. The eye sees it, the brain interprets.  But what is a box? A shape, a container, a memory of a past confinement.  The mind doesn't just see, it remembers, it anticipates, it builds stories from the fragments.  It judges, it sifts, it chooses what to hold onto, what to cast aside.

Attention, a flickering flame in the vast darkness. It dances, it flickers, it burns bright on a single point, then fades, leaving everything else to drift.  A name spoken in a crowd, a single blade of grass against the dust.  The mind filters, it protects, it prioritizes.

And memory. A phantom limb, a ghost in the machine.  The past lingers, a faint scent, a half-remembered dream.  Sensory, working, long-term – these are just labels, attempts to categorize the untamable.  Memories cling to the brain like barnacles to a hull, some smooth and polished, others rough and jagged.

How is knowledge stored?  A network?  A map?  A tapestry woven from threads of experience?  Perhaps it's something else entirely, a language spoken only by neurons, a symphony of chemical signals.

The truth, like the brain itself, remains elusive.  A mystery hidden in plain sight, a labyrinth waiting to be explored.

The air hung thick with the dust of some long-gone world. Huxley, he saw it coming, this brave new dawn. A sun bleached and sterile, a sky choked with the smoke of progress.  He built this world, this *Brave New World*, to show us the price of comfort, the cost of forgetting. They chased happiness like a phantom, these people, conditioned from birth to believe in the illusion. They were cogs in a machine, oiled by pleasure and ignorance.

He saw through it, Huxley did. Through the World Controller's blinding light, through the manufactured contentment. He smelled the rot beneath the surface, the stench of homogeny and reification. These were not men and women, but products, their souls ground down and molded into conformity. They  were slaves to the system, their minds dulled by the constant hum of false consciousness.

He spoke their language, Huxley did. He used their words, their terms - *capitalism*, *proletariat*, *hegemony*. He laid bare the truth, the gnawing emptiness at the heart of their 'perfect' world. They thought they were free, these people, but they were bound by invisible chains, forged in the fires of consumerism.  

And love? Love was a forgotten relic, a whisper in the wind.  The touch of another human being was reduced to a transaction, a fleeting moment of manufactured intimacy.  They were shadows, these people, their individuality extinguished by the relentless glare of their own desires. 

Huxley saw it all, the darkness lurking behind the facade. He knew that true freedom was not found in the pursuit of pleasure, but in the acceptance of pain, in the embrace of the human condition. He left us with a warning, a stark reminder that the pursuit of happiness can lead to the greatest of tragedies.

The limestone dust lay thick on the campus. Four and a half semesters. That's how long I'd been here, a boy adrift in this sea of brick and mortar. East Halls they called it, the place they shoved you when you first came in, like a stray dog in a holding pen. The damned place was a world away from Willard, a godforsaken trek across barren fields and asphalt plains. Twenty-five minutes on foot, they said. More like an hour when the wind sliced through you like a butcher's blade. The old timers, they talked of it as a different time, these halls swallowed by fields, a forgotten wilderness. Now it was choked with new buildings, a monument to their hunger for growth. The Creamery, the health center, all rising like tombstones in the dust. But the ground beneath still remembers. It remembers the emptiness, the silence. 

A friend, a brother in this struggle, he'd come back to the bike. Years he'd been away, but the truth of it never fades: "Bikes," he said, his voice rough like gravel, "The only way to move." A bowl of gruel and a man's will, that's all it takes. Thirty miles, maybe more. I saw it this year, the truth of it. Off-campus now, just like those dorms, a world away from the heart of things. But I bought a bike. A salvation. Twenty-five minutes, maybe an hour, cut to five if the wind's at your back. Pollock Road, that black scar cutting through the campus, it's not a kind road. But it's the shortest path.  Time is a thief, they say. And it's stealing mine.  Walking, they say, good for the soul. But the soul has no time for sentiment. A bike, it's freedom. It's the only way to outrun the dust.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).

Exposition means telling the audience what happened, typically in simple prose.  In film, the exposition happens when one character tells another a core-dump of information ala "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner."  In fiction, the author's doing the telling.

An example is in order.  As you are reading a story, you are told that the heroine met her beloved at such a place and time, that they were married in a gala fashion, and that her husband was murdered in front of her eyes.  You would not expect this entire sequence to take two pages, during which time both he and she only get two lines of dialogue each.  You would expect the author to spend some time on the husband's character, evidencing by his speech and manner how deeply he loves his wife, and you would equally expect the heroine to show through big and small ways how much his presence in her life changed and enriched her (especially if the story were to tell you flat out later that this was the case).  A proper introduction to the husband's character would allow you to become emotionally involved with his fate and would give you insight into the heroine's character: what she saw in him, how deep their bond was, clues about her thoughts and beliefs and dreams as reflected through the prism of his eyes, and so on.  You would mourn his death with her, and so grow more connected to the heroine herself.

In short, you would expect meat on the simple bone of the storyline: "They met, they married, he died."

As a writer, you need to provide that meat.  (*looks at metaphor, sighs, plunges onward*)  Sometimes it is tempting to rush past certain things.  Perhaps you're introducing a new character and you know he used to be in the Air Force, and he's the night manager of a gas station now, and he was married twice, no kids, likes to go fishing on the weekends, secretly dreams of owning the gas station someday and had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

I watched two newscast’s from Columbus, Ohio. The first one that was “live” was NBC 4 this morning (August 13, 2011). The lead story was about a man in Ashley, Ohio who had stabbed his wife, it did not state her name however his name was Shad Hostettler. They showed his mug shot and he looked like pure evil. They devoted only about two minutes to this story as it was developing. The only details they provide he had stabbed her multiple times and had been arrested. I think they spent an appropriate amount of time on this story. 
	The second story was about an early morning shooting of Travis Buyers, 18. He was shot in the Sharon Woods area and had been critically injured; there had been no arrests made at the time or any suspects. The SWAT Team was investigating the crime. This story seemed to be short, and I believe that might have been due to the fact this was a “black” man or a black neighborhood. I noticed (and have for years) that minorities are glossed over when they are a victim of a crime. If say a “white” child or adult is kidnapped or missing or a victim of a crime the media goes nuts; but if a minority person it’s lucky if it is even mentioned.
